H0.text: Electricity conductors are poor because highly reactive nonmetals, which only accept electrons and do not give them up, make them.

H1.text: Alloys are poorly formed by highly reactive nonmetals that only accept electrons and do not give them up.

H2.text: Insulators are poor for highly reactive nonmetals, which only accept electrons and do not give them up.

H3.text: Electromagnets are poor when made from highly reactive nonmetals that only accept electrons and do not give them up.

A4.text: Calcium and the alkali metals have the best resistivity-density products, but are rarely used for conductors due to their high reactivity with water and oxygen, and lack of physical strength.

A5.text: In metals, the Fermi level lies in the conduction band (see Band Theory, above) giving rise to free conduction electrons.

A6.text: Good electrical conductivity occurs when there is metallic bonding, however the electrons in some nonmetals are not metallic.

A7.text: Good electrical conductivity is seen in carbon (as graphite, along its planes), arsenic, and antimony.

A8.text: Electronegativity is the tendency for an atom of a given chemical element to attract shared electrons.

A9.text: A metal conducts electricity at a temperature of absolute zero, which is a consequence of delocalized states at the Fermi energy.

A10.text: In semiconductors like silicon and nonmetals like strontium titanate have an energy gap between the highest filled electron states (the valence band) and the lowest empty states (the conduction band).
